bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Howard A. Kelly, February 15, 1907

div1.p: Moran provides his autobiography, including his experiences as a participant in the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Howard A. Kelly, February 15, 1907
div1.opener:
L
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
Panama, February 15, 1907.
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
1418 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Doctor Kelly:-
div1.p:
Yours of the 4th instant to hand. Agreeable to your wish
that I write you something of my life prior to submitting to the experiments
at Camp Lazear, etc., I beg to state that the task becomes an easy one
since there is so little to tell of interest or worthy of special record.
However, what little there is may be summed up as follows:

Age at present thirty-one. Born in Ireland. Came to the United States
when but a small chap and made the voyage alone. Parents lived out their
lives in Ireland. Knew the English alphabet at the age of three. At the
age of eight had absorbed and was saturated with the biographies of
George Washington and Robert Emmett, hence my desire to come to the United
States. On arrival in the States went to Ohio and was raised there under my
brother's care. Education: High School, supplemented by a special course in
Book-keeping, Accounting, Commercial Law, and penmanship, receiving, on
completion of the Course, the imposing title of “Bachelor of Commercial
Science”. First regular employment was that of Hotel Clerk at the Central
Hotel, Beaver Falls, Penna. In 1897 enlisted in the U. S. Army Hospital
Corps as a Private, at Washington Barracks, D. C. First six months of my
term of enlistment was served at the Hospital School of Instruction,
Washington Barracks. (At this period I made up my mind I was one of the
men set aside by Providence to practice Medicine and I promised myself that,
at the expiration of my term of enlistment, I would take up the study of
Medicine, a promise which I kept although I have never been able to complete
the Course.) Transferred to Fort Mott, N. J. in 1898. Tried to be sent
to Cuba, but failed. Transferred to Fort Delaware, Del., same year, and
later transferred to Bedloes Island (Liberty Island), New York Harbor and
promoted from Private to the grade of Acting Hospital Steward. Early in
1899 transferred to Cuba with the Army of Occupation. Assigned to duty at
Military Hospital No. 1, Havana (Under Spanish rule known as Hospital
Alfonso XIII). Same year transferred to Guanajay Barracks, Cuba and later
in same year transferred to Columbia Barracks, Quemados, Cuba, for duty at
the hospital for the Seventh Cavalry and other troops stationed at that
Post. Honorably discharged from the U. S. Army with “Character: EXCELLENT”
on July 3, 1900. Was appointed Clerk at Headquarters of General Fitzhugh
Lee which position I held until the Department of Western Cuba was dis-
continued. About this time was approached by Dr. Roger Post Ames, an Army
Surgeon, who told me he was authorized to offer volunteers for experiments
at Camp Lazear $500. Doctor Ames being a friend of mine and interested in
my plans to study medicine advised me to accept the proposition, using the
money thus obtained to help defray my expenses at College. Told him I would
$100
Dr. H. A. K.
(2)
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
sleep over it and let him have an answer in the morning, which I did, to the
effect that I would undergo experiments but without compensation. Entered
Camp Lazear as an experimental patient and got good and tired of the proposit
-ion before I had had my case. Was not allowed to leave Camp. Honor system
was in vogue among us. Doctor Reed was wont to tell me, when I complained
of the tiresome camp life, that he would give me my dose next day but it
was two months from the date on which I entered Camp until I was sent to the
Yellow Fever Hospital as a pet patient. The Major kept me busy with Reports
and other clerical work part of the time while I was in Camp. Was bitten
once by a mosquito confined in a test tube. This was about two weeks after
I entered the Camp. No results. Was the “Star” patient and the first to
enter the “Mosquito House”, triple-doored and muslin-lined for this special
purpose. Audience on the other side of the wire screen: Doctors Reed and
Carrol and one or two others whom I do not now remember. Bitten by seven
mosquitoes in the morning and by five or six in the afternoon, all taking
their fill of good Irish-American blood. On December 24th I bet five dollars
with one of the boys who was taking the experiments in the “Infected Bedding
and Clothing Building” that I would eat Christmas Dinner with them in Camp.
Christmas Day about 11 A. M. I took my own temperature and I found it to be
101 F. By noon it was 102 F. but as I did not want the “Boys” to have the
laugh at my expense I ate as much dinner as the circumstances and prudence
would admit. None of them suspected that I had fever. Sent to Yellow
Fever Ward Christmas afternoon. First three days could not locate my pains-
- they were all through my body. Did not yell or make any fuss. Made up
my mind I was not going to act the baby and stuck to it. Out of Hospital in
fourteen days. Two weeks convalescing. Meantime, to make sure that I
really had had yellow fever they injected the blood of another man into my
circulatory apparatus. This man had a good straight attack of Y. F. No
results, as expected. After leaving Cuba commenced the study of Medicine
in the University of Virginia but was never able to complete the Course.
Foolish and ill-advised investments caused me to give up.

Trusting this will prove of some use to you and hoping you will
pardon its disconnected makeup, it being the best of which I am capable,
I am, with very kindest regards to you and yours,
